unnormalised: Okay, here's a Quora post on "Urban Gym Culture" in the "Lifestyle & Wellness" category:
normalised: Here's the normalized version of the Quora post:

unnormalised: **What's the vibe like in urban Indian gyms these days? Is it all protein shakes and six-packs?**
normalised: **What's the vibe like in urban Indian gyms these days? Is it all protein shakes and six-packs?**

unnormalised: Hey folks! So, I've been hitting the gym in Bangalore (near Koramangala, specifically) for a few years now, and I've definitely seen a shift. It's more than just lifting weights and chasing that "perfect" body.
normalised: Hey folks! So, I've been hitting the gym in Bangalore (near Koramangala, specifically) for a few years now, and I've definitely seen a shift. It's more than just lifting weights and chasing that "perfect" body.

unnormalised: While protein shakes and aspiring six-packs *are* still a thing (let's be real, who doesn't want to look good in a Kurta?), the culture is evolving. You've got people from all walks of life – college students from IIM-B, young professionals from Infosys, even Dr. Sharma from down the street – all working towards different fitness goals.
normalised: While protein shakes and aspiring six-packs *are* still a thing (let's be real, who doesn't want to look good in a Kurta?), the culture is evolving. You've got people from all walks of life – college students from I I M B, young professionals from Infosys, even Doctor Sharma from down the street – all working towards different fitness goals.

unnormalised: It's not always about aesthetics anymore. There's a growing emphasis on functional fitness, mental wellbeing, and overall health. Think yoga sessions alongside Zumba classes, and people swapping recipes for healthy dosas instead of *just* comparing protein supplements. My gym even has a dedicated meditation zone now.
normalised: It's not always about aesthetics anymore. There's a growing emphasis on functional fitness, mental wellbeing, and overall health. Think yoga sessions alongside Zumba classes, and people swapping recipes for healthy dosas instead of *just* comparing protein supplements. My gym even has a dedicated meditation zone now.

unnormalised: Of course, you still have the hardcore folks who religiously track their macros and spend hours lifting serious weight. But there's also a large community of people just trying to improve their health and manage stress levels, especially with the crazy Bangalore traffic and demanding work lives. My local gym spans over 5000 sq ft, and it's *always* bustling!
normalised: Of course, you still have the hardcore folks who religiously track their macros and spend hours lifting serious weight. But there's also a large community of people just trying to improve their health and manage stress levels, especially with the crazy Bangalore traffic and demanding work lives. My local gym spans over five thousand square feet, and it's *always* bustling!

unnormalised: The pricing is also quite variable. You can find anything from Rs. 1500/month to Rs. 5000/month, depending on the amenities and location.
normalised: The pricing is also quite variable. You can find anything from rupees one thousand five hundred per month to rupees five thousand per month, depending on the amenities and location.

unnormalised: Honestly, the urban gym culture in India is becoming way more inclusive and holistic. You'll definitely see the sculpted bodies, but you'll also find support, community, and a shared dedication to becoming healthier versions of ourselves. So ditch the excuses and find a gym that fits *your* needs! What are *your* experiences like? Let me know in the comments!
normalised: Honestly, the urban gym culture in India is becoming way more inclusive and holistic. You'll definitely see the sculpted bodies, but you'll also find support, community, and a shared dedication to becoming healthier versions of ourselves.
